EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The top priority of Great American Appetizer, Monroe facility is to provide a healthy and safe work environment for its employees and the surrounding community.  In this effort Great American Appetizer, Monroe facility has developed strict policies and procedures to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous chemical release.  The Process Safety Management (PSM) program acts as a gatekeeper of these policies and procedures.



The requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health AdministrationA?s (OSHA) PSM Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 mirrors that of Risk ManagementA?s Prevention Program 3 and therefore been integrated.  Of the 14 PSM elements 13 focus on accidental release prevention and one on emergency planning and response.  It is the commitment of management and employees to follow the established procedures and seek new ways for improvement. 



The facility has developed an Emergency Action Plan with the responsibility to notify the Monroe Fire Department of an incident for a timely response.  Trained Great American Appetizer personnel will initiate safety systems as they evacuate to minimize the impact of the emergency.  Once the Fire Department arrive on-scene they will assume the role of Incident Commander and have control the incident.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

Great American Appetizer, Monroe facility is a frozen specialty food manufacturer located in Monroe, North Carolina.  The manufacturing process includes refrigerated spaces and production equipment that utilize anhydrous ammonia as the refrigerant.  Anhydrous ammonia is a regulated substance under the Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions, 40 CFR 68.  The regulated substance is anhydrous ammonia with a total inventory charge of 45,500 lbs which is over the threshold quantity of 10,000 lbs.  Since the facility is also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health AdministrationA?s PSM Standa

rd 29 CFR 1910.119, Program 3 is required.



GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS  



EPAA?s Risk Management Prevention Program 3, 40 CFR Part 68(D) and OSHAA?s Process Safety Management Standard 29 CFR 1910.119 outline the facilities accidental release prevention program.  Included are 13 Chemical Specific Prevention steps implemented by Great American Appetizer, Monroe and are summarized below.



Employee Participation A? Employees are given shared responsibility with management in the continued evolution of the program.

Process Safety Information A? Chemical, equipment, and system information has been compiled to ensure the safe design and operation.

Process Hazard Analysis A? What-if checklist completed to identify potential hazards and minimize their impact.

Operating Procedures A? Standard Operating Procedures developed to ensure the safe operation of the process.

Training A? Training program established and operators trained to ensure the safe operation of the process.

Contractors A? Contractor program established to ensure only qualified and trained contractor work on or near the process.

Pre-Startup Safety Review A? Procedures and checklist developed to ensure all safety requirements completed before startup of new or modified process.

Mechanical Integrity A? Program developed to ensure equipment and systems installed per design specifications and maintained per manufacturer recommendations and good engineering practices.

Hot Work Permit A? Permit program established to prevent the potential of fire/explosion resulting from hot work near hazardous chemicals.

Management of Change A? Procedures established to manage process changes to ensure the integrity of the PSM program is maintained.

Incident Investigations A? Procedures established to investigate releases that resulted in or could have resulted in a catastrophic release of a hazardous chemical to prevent reoccurrence.

Compliance Audits A? Proced

ures established to periodically review program implementation and to correct as necessary.

Trade Secrets A? Policy implemented to provide all necessary information regardless of trade secrets to ensure the employee safety.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There is no Five-Year Accident History.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Great American Appetizer, Monroe facility does not respond to emergencies.  The facility does have an Emergency Action Plan (EAP).  The EAP complies with the requirements of OSHA's Emergency Action Plan Standard 1910.38 including procedures to notify of fire and other emergencies and safety evacuate and account for its employees.  The EAP has been coordinated with the Monroe Fire Department.

 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Great American Appetizer, Monroe facility is proactive on performing audits and hazard analysis per their Process Safety Management and Risk Management programs.  Any areas for improvement during these audits and hazard analysis are identified and corrective actions are recommended.  All recommendations are promptly addressed.
